awd_titl_txt: CIF: SMALL: Toward a Molecular Computer: Scaling up Programmable single-molecule Junctions Based on DNA self-assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
The field of molecular electronics aims to exploit single-molecules as the main building blocks for creating electronic circuitry. This would allow the unprecedented miniaturization of computers and many electronics with enhanced data transfer speed, storage efficacy, and signal processing. While some single molecule- and carbon nanotube-transistors have been created, no complex and functional electrical circuits have been fabricated. One fundamental challenge in the fabrication of single-molecule electronics is to create a metal electrode junction with nanometer gaps in a reliable, reproducible, and mass-producible manner. The goal of this project is to discover ways to fabricate such junctions using DNA-based origami nanostructures as templates. DNA based self-assembly has the potential to dramatically decrease the manufacturing cost of electronic devices compared with lithography techniques, while reducing the environmental footprint. This project will provide interdisciplinary research training for graduate and undergraduate students from computer science, biochemistry, material science, to nanofabrication, which is relevant for industrial and academic careers. Through "Outreach and Pre-college Programs" high school students from minority backgrounds will participate in laboratory research and take classes during the summer months to become acquainted with the fields of computer science, engineering and nanotechnology. 

This award will use self-assembled DNA nanostructures as templates to organize anisotropic nanoparticles into rationally-designed architectures with precisely controlled position and orientation at the nanometer scale. This work will provide a novel platform for fabricating scalable and cost-effective metallic electrodes which could be used to: a) integrate multiple single-molecule components in parallel, and b) study electron transferring of various molecules in a reliable and reproducible manner. The research and findings constitute an important step towards the fabrication of the new generation of integrated molecular circuits for miniaturization of computers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to utilize bottom-up self-assembly for the fabrication and organization of nanoscale materials with unparalleled precision. By manipulating anisotropic nanoparticles that possess distinctive properties, we have addressed critical issues of aggregation and shape restrictions via DNA self-assembly. This method has wide-ranging potential applications; it could significantly miniaturize and enhance the performance of computer chips by enabling the precise placement of tiny conductive elements. Moreover, the technique facilitates the development of new materials with custom magnetic, catalytic, or reactive properties, benefiting areas from data storage to environmental clean-up. Through advancing nanoscale engineering complexity, DNA self-assembly is poised to transform the landscape of electronics and materials science.

Throughout the course of this research, supported by this award, we have advanced in three main directions:

  1. Design and Manipulation of Anisotropic Nanoparticles: Our work has capitalized on the flexibility of DNA structures to engineer nanomotifs customized to particular sizes and shapes. These motifs are crucial for the manipulation of nanomaterials, such as gold nanorods (AuNRs) and gold nanotriangles (AuNTs). We have innovated two new 3D DNA origami triangles to dictate the positioning and orientation of these nanoparticles, resulting in nanoclusters with controlled placement and novel plasmonic interactions. Our tailored DNA designs offer a versatile foundation for assembling nanostructures to specific requirements.
  2. Assembly of Large Nanoparticle Arrays: We have tackled the challenge of assembling larger nanoparticle arrays in solution, especially those containing multiple nanoparticles. A novel surface-assisted diffusion approach, relying on DNA stacking interactions modulated by monovalent and divalent ion concentrations on the mica surface, was implemented. The resulting well-oriented gold nanorod arrays are large enough to be integrated with nanofabrication patterns for the creation of electronic devices.
  3. Pattern Transfer to Conductive Substrates: Arranging nanoparticle patterns on conductive substrates is essential for practical applications. We developed an efficient method to transfer these patterns from mica to various substrates such as silicon, silicon carbide, and aluminum. This method, requiring only a simple pretreatment with polymers to increase substrate hydrophobicity and the application of heat release paper, circumvents the difficulty of growing patterns directly on diverse materials and streamlines the process for widespread application.

Our findings offer a novel blueprint for the potential of DNA self-assembly in the field of nanoscale fabrication. The methodologies we have developed not only improve the precision of nanoparticle organization but also clear the path for their real-world application in electronic devices.

A cohort of graduate and undergraduate students was integral to the project, gaining expertise in multidisciplinary fields including biochemistry, nanotechnology, materials science, and engineering. They were given opportunities to share their research through peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations. The National Science Foundation's support has been vital in achieving these educational and research milestones.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2023
Modified by: Risheng Wang
